channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-3116] COSNumber NumberFormatException for large number
item.description:
When trying to load a pdf containing the following:
<</Type/Pattern/TilingType 2/Resources 52 0 R/XStep 32767/BBox[- -  ]/Matrix[0.61 0 0 -0.601 0 0.319]/YStep 32767/Length 28563/Filter/FlateDecode/PatternType 1/PaintType 1>>stream
I get a NumberFormatException in
at org.apache.pdfbox.cos.COSNumber.get(COSNumber.java:109)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseDirObject(BaseParser.java:929)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseCOSArray(BaseParser.java:648)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseDirObject(BaseParser.java:856)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseCOSDictionaryValue(BaseParser.java:148)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseCOSDictionaryNameValuePair(BaseParser.java:272)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseCOSDictionary(BaseParser.java:205)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.BaseParser.parseDirObject(BaseParser.java:844)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.COSParser.parseFileObject(COSParser.java:751)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.COSParser.parseObjectDynamically(COSParser.java:720)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.COSParser.parseObjectDynamically(COSParser.java:651)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.COSParser.parseDictObjects(COSParser.java:612)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.PDFParser.initialParse(PDFParser.java:203)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdfparser.PDFParser.parse(PDFParser.java:230)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDDocument.load(PDDocument.java:972)
at org.apache.pdfbox.pdmodel.PDDocument.load(PDDocument.java:876)

Adobe Reader and Chrome consider it a valid pdf and it load it.

I cannot share the PDF because of copyright issues, but I reproduced it with :"pdfbox\src\test\resources\input\rendering\source.pdf" from pdfbox-2.0.0-RC1-src.zip.
Changing the value 0 from "/BBox [0 0 2480 3508]" to -
throws the exception.

Using "new COSFloat(number)" works in this case.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: I could fix this, i.e. by trying new COSFloat(number) as "Plan B" if a NumberFormatException is thrown. But after I did, a new error came up, because some number is "-infinity" so we're not really getting forward. The numbers you show are smaller than 1E-300, but float MIN_VALUE = 1.401298464324817E-45f.
I think the PDF spec has an implementation note on the minimum size of a real. It's not a requirement but it might be a good lead to follow.

Commit 1715631 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1715631 ]

PDFBOX-3116: try returning a float if an integer is very large
This fixes a problem that might happen, but it doesn't fix the issue itself.

I've added COSDouble class. Minimum and maximum values for double type are much better than for float. When we use COSFloat, we get exception:

But when we use COSDouble:

Also the problem is (partially) resolved, I think.

I am not persuaded that this should be done - the PDF specification has a segment "implementation limits" which mentions the largest real value, and it is 3.4E38 which is Float.MAX_VALUE. And having a classcastexception instead of a numberformatexception is not really an improvement

I agree, this should not be done. Acrobat Pro's official API uses a 32-bit fixed point format for these kinds of numbers. Readers really aren't expected to - or even likely to be using - double precision.

Commit 1726482 from lehmi in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1726482 ]

PDFBOX-3116: check MIN/MAX values of the given number and replace them if to out of bounds

We already use a BigDecimal as internal representation for a COSFloat. I've simply added a check for MIN/MAX values, too huge or too small values are replaced with +/-Float.MAX_VALUE respectively +/-Float.MIN_NORMAL which should be in line with the spec

are you sure about this?

+                floatValue = Float.MAX_VALUE;
+                floatValue *= floatValue == Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY ? 1 : -1;

IMHO this would always return -Float.MAX_VALUE.

Commit 1726491 from lehmi in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1726491 ]

PDFBOX-3116: fixed calculation for positive/negative MAX-values
Yes, you are right, I've already fixed that. Thanks!!

Commit 1726531 from lehmi in branch 'pdfbox/branches/1.8'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1726531 ]

PDFBOX-3116: check MIN/MAX values of the given number and replace them if to out of bounds
